Title: SOP for Cleaning of Paste Kettle.

1.0 Objective: To lay down the cleaning procedure for the Paste Kettle.

2.0 Scope: This SOP shall be applicable for the Paste Kettle used in the Granulation area of the Production department.

3.0 Responsibility:
3.1 Execution: Operator
3.2 Checking: Pharmacist and above

4.0 Accountability: HOD - Production

5.0 Procedure:
5.1: Fill the vessel with 75 liters of potable water and start steam. Boil the water in the vessel until any material adhered to the vessel is removed.
5.2: Drain out the boiled water; scrub if necessary.
5.3: Wash with "Teepol" solution and rinse with 25 liters of potable water until all the residue is washed off.
5.4: Finally rinse with about 25 liters of purified water.
5.5: Wipe out with a clean dry lint-free cloth.
5.6: Finally wipe with a 70% v/v solution of Isopropyl Alcohol (IPA).
5.7: Affix the Cleaned label and fill the Equipment Log Book (Annexure-I).
5.8: Re-clean if not used within 72 hours.

6.0 Abbreviations:
- SCP: Standard Cleaning Procedure
- IPA: Isopropyl Alcohol

SOP for Validation of Oven for Depyrogenation

1.0 OBJECTIVE: To lay down the procedure for validation of the depyrogenation oven using Endotoxin indicator vials.

2.0 SCOPE: This procedure is applicable to validate the oven for the depyrogenation cycle.

3.0 RESPONSIBILITY:
3.1 Doing: Technical Assistant (Microbiologist)/Executive
3.2 Checking: Executive/Manager

4.0 ACCOUNTABILITY: Head of the Department

5.0 PROCEDURE:
FREQUENCY: Every Three Months
5.1: Reconstitute the Endotoxin indicator vial with LRW as per the labeled claim; vortex for 1 minute at every 10-minute interval up to 30 minutes.
5.2: Distribute the quantity of Endotoxin indicator into 10 pyrogen-free vials under LAF (equivalent to 10,000 EU/vial).
5.3: Label vials 1-9 and keep one vial for positive control, wrapping with parafilm.
5.4: Place the nine vials at different locations in the oven as per the location chart and operate the cycle as per SOP.
5.5: Keep one vial unexposed as a positive control.
5.6: After completion of the cycle, take all nine vials from the oven and bring them to room temperature.
5.7: Reconstitute all vials in 1 ml LRW and vortex for five minutes.
5.7.1: (One vial) For Positive Control: Dilute up to 0.125 and 0.25 EU/ml
5.7.2: (Nine vials) For Sample: Assuming 3 log reduction (i.e., each vial containing 10 EU/ml). Dilute up to 0.125 EU/ml with LRW, as per the dilution scheme given in Annexure-I.
5.8: Perform the LAL test on all dilutions of 0.125 EU/ml and on the positive control of 0.125 & 0.25 EU/ml, along with a negative control with LRW, in duplicate.
5.9: All nine vials (0.125 EU/ml) must be negative for gel formation, and the positive control should be positive.
5.10: Calculate as per Annexure-II and record the results.
5.11: Interpretation of results:
5.11.1: The positive control must be positive & the exposed vials must be negative, indicating >3 log reduction of Endotoxin.
5.11.2: If the exposed vial shows positive results, proceed to revalidation.
5.11.3: If revalidation of the exposed vials shows positive results, rectify the oven problem and repeat the cycle.
5.12 Acceptance Criteria: There should be >3 log reduction of Endotoxin.

6.0 ABBREVIATIONS:
6.1: °C = Degree Centigrade
6.2: EU = Endotoxin Units
6.3: ml = Milliliter
6.4: LAL = Limulus Amebocyte Lysate
6.5: LRW = LAL Reagent Water
6.6: PC = Positive Endotoxin Indicator Control

SOP for Cleaning of Cad Mill

1.0 OBJECTIVE: To lay down the cleaning procedure for the Cad Mill.

2.0 SCOPE: This SCP shall be applicable for the Cad Mill used in the Granulation area of the Production department.

3.0 RESPONSIBILITY:
3.1 Execution: Operator
3.2 Checking: Pharmacist and above

4.0 ACCOUNTABILITY: HOD - Production

5.0 PROCEDURE:
5.1: Put 'OFF' the electrical supply and cover the motor and starter with a polythene bag.
5.2: Remove the hopper, blade chamber, screen, and blades, and clean with 25 liters of potable water.
5.3: Further clean with a 2.5% 'Teepol' solution using a scrubber. Rinse thoroughly with 25 liters of potable water.
5.4: Apply 20 liters of hot water to all the cleaned items and allow the water to drain. Finally, rinse with about 30 liters of purified water.
5.5: Wipe out with a dry clean lint-free cloth and with 70% IPA.
5.6: Assemble the parts, affix the 'Cleaned' label, and fill the 'Equipment Log Book' (Annexure-I).
5.7: Re-clean if not used within 72 hours.

6.0 ABBREVIATIONS:
SCP: Standard Cleaning Procedure
IPA: Isopropyl Alcohol

Title: Standard Cleaning Procedure for Tablet Compression Machine

1.0 Objective: To lay down the cleaning procedure for the Tablet Compression Machine.

2.0 Scope: This SCP shall be applicable for the Tablet Compression Machine used in the compression area of the Production department.

3.0 Responsibility:
3.1 Execution: Operator
3.2 Checking: Pharmacist and above

4.0 Accountability: HOD - Production

5.0 Procedure:
5.1 Put 'OFF' the electric supply before the cleaning operation and disconnect the supply cable.
5.2 Remove the guard, hopper, feed frame, punches, and dies. Wipe off all the surplus powder remaining on the turret. Remove the powder with the help of a vacuum cleaner. Wipe the oil/grease used for lubrication of cam tracks, punches, dies, and pressure rollers with a cotton cloth. Clean the other parts with nylon brushes if required.
5.3 Clean the hopper, feed frame, and accessories with 25 liters of potable water, and finally rinse with 25 liters of purified water.
5.4 Clean all other parts mentioned above with a 70% v/v solution of Isopropyl Alcohol (IPA).
5.5 Wipe all the parts with a clean, lint-free dry cloth.
5.6 The cleaned machine should be adequately covered.
5.7 All dies and punches after cleaning are to be smeared with food-grade oil.
5.8 Fix the 'Cleaned' label and fill the 'Equipment Log Book.'
5.9 Re-clean if not used within 72 hours.

IPA: Isopropyl Alcohol

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Entering the Inoculation Room

1.0 Objective: To describe the procedure for entering the Inoculation Room.

2.0 Scope: This procedure is applicable whenever any person enters the Inoculation Room.

3.0 Responsibility:
3.1 Doing: Lab Assistant / Technical Assistant (Microbiologist) / Executive
3.2 Checking: Executive / Manager

4.0 Accountability: Head of the Department

5.0 Procedure:
5.1 Preparation Before Entry:
5.1.1 Remove wristwatches and jewelry before entering the Inoculation Room.
5.1.2 Wash hands with soap, then rinse with 70% Isopropyl Alcohol (I.P.A.) solution, allowing hands to air dry.

5.2 Entry into Airlock I:
5.2.1 Remove slippers outside and enter Airlock I of the Inoculation Room.
5.2.2 Take a sterile gown from the drum in Airlock I.
5.2.3 Ensure that the door to the other side is closed while preparing.
5.2.4 Use a stainless steel stool if necessary while gowning.

5.3 Gowning Procedure:
5.3.1 Wear the gown and close the zipper securely.
5.3.2 Properly tuck the head cover to ensure hair is covered.
5.3.3 Take a pair of sterile disposable gloves from the drawer and wear them without touching the outer surface.
5.3.4 Discard any gloves that are ruptured or have pinholes.
5.3.5 Tuck the sleeve ends properly inside the gloves.
5.3.6 Wear slippers provided in Airlock I.

5.4 Final Preparations Before Entry:
5.4.1 Spray both hands with 70% I.P.A. and allow to air dry.
5.4.2 Open the door to the Inoculation Room using the elbow, ensuring fingers do not touch any surfaces, and verify that the door to Airlock I is closed.

5.5 Conduct Inside the Inoculation Room:
Note: Disinfect gloves frequently with sterile 70% Isopropyl Alcohol provided in the Inoculation Room.
5.5.1 Switch off the U.V. light and switch on the tube light.

5.6 Exiting the Inoculation Room:
5.6.1 Follow the same sequence in reverse order when exiting the Inoculation Room.
5.6.2 Collect all used garments and gloves in the closed bucket provided in Airlock I.

6.0 Abbreviations:
6.1 S.S.: Stainless Steel
6.2 I.P.A.: Isopropyl Alcohol
6.3 %: Percentage
6.4 U.V.: Ultraviolet

Write an SOP for Planned Preventive Maintenance Program.

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Planned Preventive Maintenance Program

1.0 Objective: To provide stepwise instructions for a planned preventive maintenance program.

2.0 Scope: This SOP is applicable for the preventive maintenance of all equipment in the production and utility areas.

3.0 Responsibility:
Technicians: Responsible for following the procedure sequentially.
Engineers: Responsible for monitoring and ensuring adherence to the procedure.
User Department and QA: Responsible for verifying the completion of Preventive Maintenance activities.

4.0 Accountability: Head of Engineering

5.0 Procedure:
5.1 Preparation of the Annual Preventive Maintenance Schedule:
5.1.1 Prepare a master Annual Maintenance Schedule for all critical equipment in the production and utility systems, including Air Handling Units and Ventilation units. This schedule will be prepared by the Engineer, checked by the Engineering Department Head, and approved by the Head of QA.
5.1.2 Prepare a master Annual Filter Cleaning Schedule for all Air Handling Units, Ventilation units, and water tank cleaning schedules. The schedule will be prepared by the Engineer, checked by the Engineering Department Head, and approved by the Head of QA.
5.1.3 Issue controlled copies of the schedule and Preventive Maintenance procedure to the engineering department for recording.

5.2 Checklist:
5.2.1 Prepare a checklist for all critical equipment in the production and utility systems, including Air Handling Units and Ventilation units.
5.2.2 The checklist must define all critical assemblies.
5.2.3 Carry out activities as per the preventive maintenance schedule and the respective SOP, referencing the checklist.

5.3 Preventive Maintenance Precautions:
5.3.1 Open the panel of the machine and clean it properly.
5.3.2 Ensure that the equipment is cleaned and free from product residues.
5.3.3 Switch off the main power supply and isolate all utilities.
5.3.4 Display a 'UNDER PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE' board at the main power supply of the equipment.
5.3.5 Use adequate tools and tackles.
5.3.6 Remove all tools, tackles, and worn-out spares from the area after maintenance.
5.3.7 Refer to the equipment manufacturer’s manual for identifying necessary spares and consumables.
5.3.8 Conduct a trial of the equipment after maintenance.

5.4 Record Keeping:
5.4.1 Document the technician's name in the ‘done by’ column, along with the date. The checker shall sign in the ‘Checked by’ column with the date upon completion in the Preventive Maintenance procedure format.
5.4.2 Maintain a common format for recording filter cleaning activities in the 'Filter Cleaning Area Log Sheet.' Keep filter cleaning records separately for each equipment/AHU in the 'Filter Cleaning Log Book' as per SOP.
5.4.3 After completion, both the doer (Engineer) and checker (Head of Engineering) shall sign the Annual Maintenance Schedule and Annual Filter Cleaning Schedule respectively.
5.4.4 If preventive maintenance is not completed as scheduled due to unforeseen reasons, it must be completed within the next 15 days. Extensions require approval from Engineering and QA Heads.
5.4.5 Enter preventive maintenance details in the respective equipment log book.
5.4.6 For new equipment, include preventive maintenance in the annual schedule, recording it in an additional maintenance schedule annexed to the SOP. At the end of the year, incorporate this equipment into the next year's schedule.

6.0 Abbreviations:
6.1 SOP: Standard Operating Procedure
6.2 QA: Quality Assurance

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Procurement, Storage, and Handling of Biological Indicators

1.0 Objective: To clearly define the procedure for procurement, storage, and handling of Biological Indicators.

2.0 Scope:
Description: This procedure is applicable for the following Biological Indicators:
2.1 B. subtilis
2.2 B. stearothermophilus

3.0 Responsibility:
3.1 Doing: Technical Assistant/Executive
3.2 Checking: Executive/Manager

4.0 Accountability: Head of the Department

5.0 Procedure:
5.1 Procurement:
5.1.1 Raise the Purchase Order (P.O.) as per the requirement for Biological Indicators.

5.2 Receipt of Material:
5.2.1 On receipt, check the physical condition of the package, labeling details, certificates, and expiry date.

5.3 Storage:
5.3.1 Store in a cool, dry place away from sterilants under lock and key.
5.3.2 Maintain the stock.

5.4 Procedure for Use:
5.4.1 Take out Biological Indicator strips from the container.
5.4.2 Follow the gowning procedure as per the SOP.
5.4.3 Enter the inoculation/microbiological room.
5.4.4 Open the container under the culture cabinet and use sterile forceps to take out the strips.
5.4.5 For steam sterilization validation, place each B. stearothermophilus strip in sterile Petri plates and proceed as per SOP.
5.4.6 For dry heat sterilization validation, wrap each strip in aluminum foil and fold properly, then proceed as per SOP.
5.4.7 Treat Biological Indicators within 2 hours.

5.5 Expiry and Disposal:
5.5.1 On expiry, if stock remains, dispose of Biological Indicators after treating in the sterilization cycle at 121°C for 30 minutes.
5.5.2 Record the disposition.

6.0 Abbreviations:
P.O.: Purchase Order
DHS: Dry Heat Sterilizer

Write an SOP for Preventive Maintenance of AHU and Ventilation Units.

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Preventive Maintenance of AHU and Ventilation Units

1.0 Objective: To provide stepwise instructions for the Preventive Maintenance of AHU and Ventilation units.

2.0 Scope: This procedure is applicable for the Preventive Maintenance of AHU and Ventilation units.

3.0 Responsibility:
Technicians: Responsible for following the procedure in a sequential manner.
Engineers: Responsible for monitoring and ensuring adherence to the procedure.
User Department and QA: Responsible for verifying the completion of Preventive Maintenance activities.

4.0 Accountability: Head of Engineering

5.0 Procedure:
5.1 Precautions:
5.1.1 Disconnect the machine from the electric supply mains.
5.1.2 Tag 'Under Preventive Maintenance' on the machine. Remove belts when checking motor rotation direction to prevent damage.
5.1.3 Ensure no tools or spanners are left on the machine after maintenance.

5.2 General Assembly (Frequency: Once a month ± 7 days):
5.2.1 Switch ‘OFF’ the main supply and display the ‘UNDER PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE’ board on the AHU.
5.2.2 Check that all nuts and bolts of the supply air filter plenum are tight and secure. Replace gaskets if necessary.
5.2.3 Inspect all duct joints for air leaks and secure with nuts and bolts or replace gaskets as needed.
5.2.4 Check the door lock and handle for damage and replace if necessary.
5.2.5 Inspect door gaskets for air leakage and replace if needed.
5.2.6 Verify that nuts and bolts of the HVAC and Ventilation unit cabinet are secure. Tighten or replace as necessary.
5.2.7 Check for air leakage from the HVAC and Ventilation unit cabinet and tighten as needed.
5.2.8 Inspect the canvas connections of the terminal branch/ blower suction and discharge; replace if damaged.
5.2.9 Check duct joints for air leakage and secure with nuts and bolts or replace gaskets if required.
5.2.10 Check the temperature of the inlet/outlet of chilled water for proper operation.
5.2.11 Check the temperature of the inlet/outlet of hot water for proper operation.
5.2.12 Tighten all nuts and bolts of the filter unit and replace any that are missing.
5.2.13 Inspect the filter unit for air/dust leakage and secure as necessary.
5.2.14 Check canvas connections on the blower suction/discharge side; replace if damaged.

5.3 Electrical Maintenance:
5.3.1 Open the machine panel and clean it.
5.3.2 Tighten all loose electrical connections.
5.3.3 Clean the contacts of the contactor.
5.3.4 Verify the relay setting of the machine motor is at the rated maximum current.
5.3.5 Check the DOL reversible starter for proper motor direction; rectify or replace as necessary.
5.3.6 Dress all cables/conduits in the panel and replace if required.
5.3.7 Switch ‘ON’ the main supply and check all sensors for functionality.

5.4 Cooling Coil Maintenance:
5.4.1 Switch ‘OFF’ the main supply.
5.4.2 Open the cooling coil section doors of the AHU.
5.4.3 Clean the surfaces of the cooling coil with a dry cloth.
5.4.4 Wash the inner surfaces of the fins with water.
5.4.5 Clean the drain and inner surfaces of the AHU with a cloth.
5.4.6 Ensure no water is stagnant in the drain. (Note: Inform the production department before cleaning the coil.)

5.5 Motor Maintenance:
5.5.1 Ensure main power supply is disconnected and utilities are isolated.
5.5.2 Clean any dust from the machine.
5.5.3 Remove all guards and main motors.
5.5.4 Dismantle the motor.
5.5.5 Check bearing conditions and replace if necessary.
5.5.6 Inspect winding insulation and rectify as needed.
5.5.7 Lubricate bearings with AP-3 or equivalent grease and reassemble.
5.5.8 Reassemble the motor.

5.6 Blower Maintenance:
5.6.1 Remove the pulleys from their position.
5.6.2 Check pulleys, keys, and keyways; rectify or replace as needed.
5.6.3 Inspect belts and replace if necessary.
5.6.4 Check bearing conditions and replace if needed.
5.6.5 Lubricate bearings with AP-3 or equivalent grease.
5.6.6 Refit the pulleys.
5.6.7 Fit the ‘V’ belts onto the pulleys.
5.6.8 Remove the ‘UNDER PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE’ tag.

5.7 Trial Operation:
5.7.1 Switch ‘ON’ the main supply to the machine.
5.7.2 Check the operation of the machine and make adjustments if necessary.
5.7.3 Monitor current drawn by the motors; it should not exceed the rated current.

6.0 Abbreviations:
6.1 SOP: Standard Operating Procedure
6.2 HVAC: Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning
6.3 UV: Ultra Violet
6.4 QA: Quality Assurance
6.5 AHU: Air Handling Unit

Title: Standard Cleaning Procedure for Octagonal Blender

3.0 Responsibility:
3.1 Execution: Operator
3.2 Checking: Pharmacist and above

4.0 Accountability: HOD - Production

5.0 Procedure:

5.1.1 Turn off the electric supply and cover all electrical parts with poly bags.

5.2 Disassembly:
5.2.1 Remove the lid and open the butterfly valve assembly.

5.3 Initial Cleaning:
5.3.1 Wipe off residual powder using a dry lint-free cloth.

5.4 Washing:
5.4.1 Wash with 50 liters of potable water at least two times until all residue is removed. Use a 2.5% “Teepol” solution and scrub parts if necessary, followed by a wash with 25 liters of hot water.

5.5 Rinsing:
5.5.1 Finally, rinse with approximately 100 liters of purified water.

5.7 Final Sanitization:
5.7.1 Wipe all parts with a 70% v/v solution of Isopropyl Alcohol (IPA).

5.8 Documentation:
5.8.1 Affix a 'Cleaned' label and fill out the Equipment Log Book.

5.9 Re-cleaning:
5.9.1 Re-clean if not used within 72 hours.

IPA: Isopropyl Alcohol

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Identification of Organisms

1.0 OBJECTIVE: To identify the organism of all cultures lying in the microbiological department or contaminants.

2.0 SCOPE: This procedure is applicable for morphological identification of organisms in all cultures lying in the microbiological laboratory and all contaminants obtained during analysis.

3.0 RESPONSIBILITY:  
  3.1 Doing: Tech. Assistant (Microbiologist)  
  3.2 Checking: Executive/Manager  

4.0 ACCOUNTABILITY: Head of the Department  

5.0 PROCEDURE:  
  5.1 Wear sterile gloves, goggles, and mask before starting the work.  
  5.2 Take a clean and dry slide and make it grease-free by passing it through a flame 3-4 times.  
  5.3 With the help of a sterile nichrome wire loop, take the growth of organisms to be identified and spread it evenly on the center of the slide. Allow it to air dry.  
  5.4 Gently pass the slide through a flame 2-3 times for fixation of the smear.  
  5.5 Wash with water and flood with Gram's iodine for one minute.  
  5.6 Wash the slide with water and decolorize with alcohol or acetone until no further violet color comes off.  
  5.7 Wash with water.  
  5.8 Counterstain with 0.5% safranin for about half a minute.  
  5.9 Wash the slide with water, air dry it, and observe the slide under a 100X immersion lens of a microscope.  
  5.10 Gram-positive bacilli & Gram-positive cocci are stained violet, and Gram-negative coccobacilli and Gram-negative cocci are stained pink in color.  
  5.11 Observe the result and report it in the respective format.

  6.2 +ve: Positive

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Preparation, Sterilization, Storage, and Growth Promotion Test of Microbiological Media

1.0 OBJECTIVE: To provide a method of preparation, sterilization, storage, and growth promotion test of microbiological media.

2.0 SCOPE: This procedure is applicable for the preparation of solid and liquid media which are to be used for microbiological testing.

3.0 RESPONSIBILITY:
  3.1 Doing: Technical Assistant
  3.2 Checking: Executive /Manager

4.0 ACCOUNTABILITY: Head of the Department

5.0 PROCEDURE:
  5.1 For liquid media preparation:
    5.1.1 Weigh the required quantity of the media powder for a specific volume in a beaker as per the instructions given on the dehydrated media bottle or media preparation sheet.
    5.1.2 If ready-made dehydrated media is not available, prepare the media as per pharmacopeia.
    5.1.3 Dissolve the media by heating with continuous stirring. For large quantities, continuously stir and add the remaining quantity of water to make up the volume. Mix properly.
    5.1.4 Adjust the pH with 0.1N HCl/0.1N NaOH if necessary.
    5.1.5 Allot the Lot No. to prepared media as per SOP.
    5.1.6 After sterilization, check the pH from one container & discard it. The pH should be within the limit.
    5.1.7 Distribute the specific volume of the media in appropriate glass containers intended for use.
    5.1.8 Plug it either with a cotton plug or metal caps.
    5.1.9 Affix the label with media details on each tube.
    5.1.10 If cotton plugs are used, cover them with wrapping paper.
    5.1.11 Unless specified, sterilize the media at 121°C for 20 minutes as per SOP.
    5.1.12 After sterilization, cool down the media at room temperature & proceed for the preincubation & Growth promotion test of the same.

  5.2 For solid media preparation:
    5.2.1 As per the instruction, weigh the specified quantity of media powder in a beaker whose capacity is double the final volume of the media to be prepared.
    5.2.2 Add an appropriate quantity of distilled water and mix it properly.
    5.2.3 Allot the Lot No. to media as per SOP.
    5.2.4 Heat and dissolve the medium constituents with constant stirring to avoid charring.
    5.2.5 Check the pH of the medium and set the pH using 0.1N HCl/0.1N NaOH if required.
    5.2.6 While in the molten state, distribute the specific volume of the media into appropriate glass containers.
    5.2.7 Seal the mouth of the glass container using cotton plugs.
    5.2.9 Cover the cotton plugs with wrapping paper.
    5.2.10 Unless specified, sterilize the media at 121°C for 20 minutes as per SOP.
    5.2.11 After completion of sterilization, solid media are used in different forms according to the requirements:
      [A] For slant preparation: Place the molten media tubes slanted and let them solidify.
      [B] For stab preparation: Keep the media tubes in the upright position and allow them to solidify.
      [C] For the preparation of plates: Pour the media into the sterile Petri dishes under LAF and let them solidify.
    5.2.12 Solid media for other purposes should be kept in the oven or water bath at a temperature between 45°C-50°C until use to keep them in the molten state.
    5.2.13 Sterile solid plates should be stored at 20°-25°C while sterile slants and stabs should be stored at freezer temperature.

  5.3 Preincubation of the media:
    5.3.1 All sterile solid as well as liquid media should be kept at 30°-35°C for 48 hrs for preincubation.
    5.3.2 After 48 hrs, if the media indicate growth (liquid media becomes hazy & solid media show some colonies), discard the contaminated media as per SOP.
    5.3.3 Allot the lot No. to each container of medium and transfer them to the 20-25°C walk-in incubator.

  5.4 Growth Promotion Test:
    5.4.1 Check the growth-promoting properties of the medium either by inoculating <100 cells/ml of control organism in the liquid media or by streaking the surface of the solid media plates with control organisms known to produce a positive reaction. For sterility test media, check the growth-promoting quality by separately inoculating duplicate test containers.
    5.4.2 During testing of total viable count, keep the positive control with any one of the indicator organisms such as B. subtilis for SCD agar, C. albicans for SD agar, and E. coli for Endo agar.
    5.4.3 The medium is said to be satisfactory if turbidity in a liquid medium is observed within 48 hrs for bacteria and 5 days for fungi. Growth on solid agar should be seen within 24-48 hrs at specific incubation conditions.
    5.4.4 After the growth promotion test, transfer all the preincubated sterile liquid medium tubes and solid medium plates to 20°-25°C for use.
    5.4.5 Store all slants & stabs at freezer temperature.

  5.5 Storage:
    5.5.1 Medium more than three weeks old should not be used for sterility purposes.
    5.5.2 Medium other than sterility tests kept at 20°-25°C should be used within one month.
    5.5.3 Slants and stabs stored at freezer temperature should be used within two months.
    5.5.4 Maintain the media preparation record.

  6.1 °C: Degree centigrade
  6.2 ml: Milliliter

Title: Standard Operating Procedure for Qualification of Vendors for Raw Materials and Packaging Materials

1.0 OBJECTIVE: To lay down the procedure for the qualification of vendors for the Raw materials and Packaging materials.

2.0 SCOPE: This SOP shall be applicable for all the incoming Raw materials and Packaging materials used for Own & Contract manufacturing sites.

3.0 RESPONSIBILITY:
  3.1 Doing: QA Officer / QA Executive
  3.2 Checking: Executive/Manager

4.0 ACCOUNTABILITY: Head- QA & QC

5.0 PROCEDURE:
  5.1 Procedure for inclusion of vendor in approved vendor list (Raw materials)
    5.1.1 New vendors shall be qualified and approved by QA department before regular supply of raw materials.
    5.1.2 Purchase department shall locate the new vendor and find out the details of products manufactured/supplied by them. In case of existing materials, Purchase department shall provide specification to the vendor.
    5.1.3 In case of RM source, after the initial assessment, Purchase department shall arrange to get the Supplier Questionnaire filled by the supplier.
    5.1.4 If the Questionnaire evaluation is found suitable, Purchase department after discussion with R&D and QA shall ask for 3 batches of samples along with certificate of analysis of in-house & Public Testing Laboratory for quality evaluation and subsequent stability studies.
    5.1.5 Purchase department shall arrange to send 3 batches of samples along with New Source Request form to R&D for quality evaluation and stability testing.
    5.1.6 R&D shall send the samples along with New Source Request Form to QA Head for evaluation.
  
  5.2 New Source Request Form
    There are three types of new sources:
    - New material from a new source.
    - Existing material from a new source.
    - New material from an existing approved source.
  
  5.3 Evaluation of a New Source
    5.3.1 QC shall analyze the samples sent by R&D as per approved specifications and testing procedures.
    5.3.2 If the samples are found to be in compliance with the specifications, QA shall send the analytical report to R&D along with the New Source Request Form.
    5.3.3 R&D, in consultation with QA, shall decide the criticality and necessity of carrying out usage test and stability studies. The necessity of carrying out machine trials shall also be evaluated by R&D, in consultation with QA / Production.
    5.3.4 R&D shall carry out the usage test and machine trials, if required. R&D will also recommend the need to do stability studies, if required, and communicate the same with other recommendations to Head QA.
    5.3.5 Following the evaluation carried out depending on the criticality of the material, the Head QA shall recommend an audit of the Supplier’s premises.
  
  5.4 Approval of New Source
    5.4.1 The facilities and operations of the supplier’s manufacturing site must be subjected to a quality audit before the materials are used. Audit shall be conducted by the respective Quality function.
    5.4.2 In case when the new material is from an already approved source, the approval may be recommended based on the pre-approval Questionnaire evaluation after completing New Source Request form.
    5.4.3 If the supplier’s facilities and operations meet requirements as documented in the audit report, then the respective Head QA shall approve the supplier.
    5.4.4 The auditor must arrange to send the signed copy of the audit report to the audited supplier.
    5.4.5 After approval, Head QA, where the material is used, shall give clearance for procurement of a limited quantity of material for use in 3 production batches and evaluate these three batches critically for quality.
    5.4.6 Purchase department shall carefully study the quality aspect and also the quantity and financial aspects of the vendor. They are as follows:
      a) Capability of the vendor to supply the required material within the period.
      b) Delivery schedule in order not to affect the production cycle.
    5.4.7 Purchase department shall find out the rates quoted by the vendor and determine whether they are competitive with respect to other vendors without compromising the quality aspects.
    5.4.8 On ensuring compliance with specifications, the vendor shall be included in the approved vendor’s list.
    5.4.9 All the suppliers of RM evaluated by the R&D dept. on the basis of process/product development parameters shall be considered as temporary vendors, and based on the commercial production supply, they shall be transferred to the approved vendor list and shall be considered as approved vendors.
    5.4.10 After vendor audit, a vendor audit report classifying the observations as critical, major, and minor with recommended corrective and preventive actions (CAPA) shall be issued to the vendor within 20 days of the audit.
    5.4.11 The Vendor shall reply to the audit report with the action plan on CAPA along with the expected date of completion of CAPA items.
    5.4.12 The quality function shall follow up with the supplier on the implementation and compliance of the CAPA items suggested in the CAPA plan.
  
  5.5 Procedure for Inclusion of Vendor in Approved Vendor List (Packaging Materials)
    5.5.1 New vendors must be qualified and approved by QA department before regular supply of packaging materials.
    5.5.2 Purchase department shall locate the new vendor and find out the details of products manufactured/supplied by them. In case of existing materials, Purchase department shall provide specification to the new vendor.
    5.5.3 For printed and primary packaging materials, vendor audit is performed by a representative of QA department and GMP Cell.
    5.5.4 Samples of printed packaging materials, if necessary, shall be submitted to QA department.
    5.5.5 Purchase department, after studying the comments of QA department, shall inform the supplier for the supply of the material.
    5.5.6 Based on the product compliance and assessment, further procurement of packaging material should be continued. On ensuring compliance with specifications, the vendor shall be included in the approved vendor’s list.
  
  5.6 Procedure for Exclusion of Vendor from Approved Vendor List
    The vendor shall be disqualified and removed from the approved vendor’s list for the following reasons:
    a) If a lot does not comply with the specification with respect to critical tests, then the vendor shall be disqualified. The vendor shall be qualified again on further evaluation and investigation.
    b) If a lot does not comply with the specification with respect to minor tests, then the vendor shall be disqualified if it is observed for 3 consecutive lots.
    c) 3 out of 10 lots fail to comply with the specification in a specified period under review.
    d) The delivery schedule is not met for 40% of supplies.
    e) The rates mentioned in the Purchase Order differ from the rates mentioned in the delivery challan and invoice.
    5.6.1 The aspects like the capability of the supplier to provide regulatory support, meet the official requirements shall be evaluated during the supplier audit.
    5.6.2 The commitment to notify changes to the company prior to implementation, e.g., change in manufacturing site, change in process, shall be taken.
    5.6.3 The commitment to investigate failure promptly in case of any failure reported shall be assured by the supplier and the capability of the supplier shall be evaluated on this front.
  
  5.7 Corrective and Preventive Action
    5.7.1 The vendor, who has been excluded from the approved vendor’s list, as well as those who are disqualified and seek inclusion, may be included only after CAPA verification of previous items on their satisfactory closure and effective implementation of CAPA.
    5.7.2 The vendor shall be made aware of the reasons for their exclusion and shall be asked for an explanation.
    5.7.3 Head Purchase, Head QA&QC, and GMP Cell shall conduct a facility audit of the vendor to ensure that a quality system exists in the organization.
    5.7.4 Carry out the discussion on other non-quality issues like delivery schedule and rate, etc.
    5.7.5 After satisfactory compliance with all the above points and ensuring the completion of the CAPA plan, the vendor shall be considered as an approved vendor.
    5.7.6 The CAPA compliance of the previous audit shall be verified in the subsequent audit.
    5.7.7 The CAPA verification documents, if any, shall be kept along with the audit and compliance report.
  
  5.8 FREQUENCY: List of approved vendors to be prepared once in two years or as & when required.

Title: Standard Operating Procedure to Avoid Airborne Contamination During Material Sampling

1.0 OBJECTIVE: To avoid airborne contamination in the material during sampling.

2.0 SCOPE: This procedure is applicable during sampling of raw material in sampling booth installed in the raw material store.

3.0 RESPONSIBILITY:
  3.1 Doing: Technical Assistant
  3.2 Checking: Executive/Manager

4.0 ACCOUNTABILITY: Head of the Department

5.0 PROCEDURE:
  5.1 Introduction
    5.1.1 It is important and most essential to avoid any airborne contamination in the material during sampling.
    5.1.2 To sample the raw material under 'Clean environment' the sampling booths are designed in which fresh air is initially sucked through core filter then 5 micron filter, before passing through HEPA filter to reduce the load on HEPA filter.
    5.1.3 Core filter and 5 micron filter are cleanable and require cleaning periodically as and when required.
    5.1.4 The recommended manometer reading is between 7 to 15 mm of water.
    5.1.5 If reading goes more than 15, it indicates choking of HEPA filter and needs replacement of HEPA filter.
    5.1.6 Whenever replacement of HEPA filter takes place, the system is to be validated w.r.t. PAO test.
    5.1.7 If reading goes down, it indicates choking of prefilter which requires cleaning. Inform engineering department for cleaning of prefilter.
  5.2 Operation of Sampling Booths
    5.2.1 Switch 'ON' the mains.
    5.2.2 Switch 'ON' the light.
    5.2.3 Start blower at slow speed one hour before the sampling.

  3.2 Checking: Executive/Manager

5.0 PROCEDURE:
  5.1 For C18, C8, C6, Phenyl, (CN, Amine, Silica column):
    5.1.1 Wash the column with the solvent used in individual product mobile phase preparation. e.g., if water is used in mobile phase preparation, then wash the column with water.

    5.1.3 Disconnect the column from the HPLC unit and store it in an allocated place.
  5.2 For Protein pack column:

    5.3.3 Flush the column with water at a flow rate of 0.6 ml/min for 2 hours.
    5.3.4 Disconnect the column from the H.P.L.C unit and store it in an allocated place.
